Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Integrated Microstructure and Melt Pool Dimension Control for Electron Beam Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) Collaborative research project is to provide fundamental and experimentally-verified guidelines for integrated control of melt pool dimensions and microstructure in electron beam additive manufacturing, a class of emerging manufacturing processes which build geometric features by locally melting metal and building it up layer-by-layer. The research approach involves numerical modeling performed at the academic institutions in conjunction with electron beam deposition experiments performed by the industrial and government collaborators. Simulation results will be presented across a wide range of electron beam powers, travel speeds, material feed rates, and deposit geometries, and will guide the choice of critical experiments conducted by the industrial and government collaborators. Models and experiments will include the effects of local tailoring of temperatures in and around the melt pool by rapid movement of the electron beam across the part surface.

If successful, the benefits of this research will include not only a fundamental understanding of how electron beam process variables relate to final part quality, but also a practical basis for simultaneous control of melt pool geometry and microstructure. This will represent a significant contribution toward qualification of electron beam manufacturing processes for aerospace and other commercial applications. Research activities will be integrated with ongoing NSF-supported educational research projects at both academic institutions. Students performing research on this project will develop a combined manufacturing, solid mechanics, heat transfer and materials background that will make them highly valuable in industry and academics.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The advancement of Electron Beam Additive Manufacturing (EBAM) processes for part fabrication and repair applications requires the ability to consistently control melt pool dimensions and resulting microstructure. Melt pool dimensional control is needed to successfully build or repair complex 3-D shapes to geometric specifications, and the resulting microstructure must be controlled to ensure suitable mechanical properties of the deposit. The need for in-situ monitoring of these processes necessitates integrated control of melt pool dimensions and resulting microstructure, where control of melt pool dimensions (which can be monitored via optical or thermal imaging) is tied to control of microstructure (which otherwise can only be determined by sectioning after a part is built).  In this way, monitoring and control of melt pool dimensions during processing will naturally lead to the control of microstructure.

The intellectual merit of this work lies in the development of "process maps" relating melt pool geometry and resulting microstructure to additive manufacturing (AM) process variables (specifically beam power and velocity). Process mapping involves the representation of experimental and/or computational model results for melt pool geometry and/or microstructural features in power-velocity space. This allows process developers to better understand how changes in process variables affect melt pool geometry and resulting microstructure for a particular material system and additive manufacturing process. The approach is general and applicable to a wide range of materials and related AM processes, as well as laser or gas metal arc welding processes. While this project initially addressed EBAM deposition of Ti-6Al-4V with a wire feed system, application of the process map approach toward integrated control of melt pool geometry and resulting microstructure has also been investigated across a range of commercially available AM processes and other material systems.

The results of this work have provided the fundamental understanding of the relationships between AM process variables, melt pool geometry and resulting microstructure required to help advance the widespread application of AM in aerospace and other industries.  Moreover, the students involved in this project have developed a combined manufacturing, solid mechanics, heat transfer and materials background that will make them highly valuable in industry and academics.  In addition to addressing a primary technical barrier to the advancement of AM processes, this work has helped to address the growing industry need for multidisciplinary engineers who are comfortable working in teams with diverse technical backgrounds.


Last Modified: 08/10/2018
Modified by: Nathan Klingbeil
